thread.title: LSU coach's thoughts on player's U of L visit
thread.title_full: LSU coach's thoughts on player's U of L visit

author: Kyle Tucker, USA TODAY Sports
title: LSU coach's thoughts on player's U of L visit
text:
LSU coach's thoughts on player's U of L visit USA Today Sports 22 hrs ago by Kyle Tucker, USA TODAY Sports © Mike Dinovo, USA TODAY Sports Mike Dinovo, USA TODAY Sports CHARLOTTE, N.C. – LSU men's basketball coach Johnny Jones said he hasn't asked five-star LSU freshman Antonio Blakeney what happened on a trip last summer that ended up in a sex worker's tell-all book alleging scandalous misconduct at the University of Louisville, but "understanding the little that we know about the situation, it's probably more between him and his God than it is him and the NCAA."
AdChoices Jones, speaking at Southeastern Conference media day Wednesday, told The Courier-Journal he believes Blakeney "had the opportunity to visit in some capacity" with college basketball's governing body about Katina Powell's book, which claims the player and his guardian both had sex with escorts while they were in a Louisville hotel during an AAU national tournament in the summer of 2014.
Powell alleges that the rendezvous was set up by former Louisville men's basketball staff member Andre McGee, who at the time was working at another school but wired money to Powell – a detail ESPN has independently verified.
"I'm not able to speak on it because it's obviously an ongoing investigation and we're not really privy to any of the information that would've come out" Jones said of Blakeney's interview with the NCAA. He added that he's "not at all" worried about the prized freshman guard's eligibility.
"We haven't been given any reason to be alarmed about anything in terms of him moving forward, in terms of his eligibility status because of an official visit that he may have taken to another school," Jones said. "I've addressed with (the team) about making sure that they support him and make sure that they rally around him and this, too, shall pass, and it will move on. But it's in the moment now and it's something that he'll grow from."
In exchange for cooperation with an investigation, NCAA rules allow for immunity to be granted to student-athletes who might otherwise find their eligibility in jeopardy. ESPN's report Tuesday included five former Louisville players or recruits who corroborated the gist of Powell's book.
Blakeney was originally scheduled to attend SEC media day, but LSU understandably found a substitute.
Kyle Tucker covers college sports for The Louisville Courier-Journal , a Gannett company.
